comments.commentBody: I agree 100%.
Plagiarism is duplicating someone else's work without acknowledging the original source of the work.

Boy this is a tough one.  As an artist, very little hasn't been done before.  This is true in all art forms.  In film, the references or homages are to the films of the past.  Art like life is a vast ground of recycling.  In the past decade or so we've seen sampling of music, sampling of newspaper photos--the Obama -Shepard Fairy image.  Its hard to slice all of this into rules to protect rights.  Original?  When Charles Mee takes dialogue from prison inmates and makes it a play--is that a play or plagiarism?  Too bad this guy didn't make it super, if he was going to take...Red Ribbon is not so good.  I prefer Brown Solo....but that's me.

"Fair Use"  was created to help artistic creativity in a sector that usually has to battle with they our resourses. The art world has change drastically, and today the artists who abuse the "fair use" has characteristics of corporations, Richard Prince is that case with his galleries, dealers and art circuits. Today the establishment art world use the "fair use" against the people who was meant to be created. "Fair use" has sense, since even a photography can be subject of art, second lectures, reinterpretations, etc. Richard Prince exhausted this lecture many years ago, he made a good point at that moment, everybody praise his work . Today, there is no more quality , conceptual or in any other form of the derivative work of Prince, he his the last end of the spectrum of "fair use" and the people who will bring "fair use" to his collapse. The fact that Prince sells for millions doesn't mean anything, that is market, and market is not necessarily related to quality or artistic creativity. Prince disqualified the artistic value of the people who stolen from just base in his position in the art world. But even if this lack of quality were real, is not an argument to took the work of others in that way and arrogance, the people regardless of his artistic qualities pay for his rent, equipments and production costs. Andy Warhol foundation should be ashamed of his arguments in defense of Prince, has should be anyone who do the same.

MariannaNYC, maybe Philip Seymour and many others would be alive if it was possible to obtain a legal supply of heroin at a reasonable cost.  Countries have implemented heroin assisted treatment programs for heroin addicts who are not able to kick heroin by other means.  These programs have been socially and financially successful.
Reminds me of the old bar band request. Can you play, "I took her to the river, but she wouldn't come across?"
There were three elections already in the last ten years alone.  It's almost as bad as Egypt there, and when the opposition starts speaking about "Holy Kiev Rus" it makes you got to wonder.

" The International Monetary Fund remains a potential source of financing to replace the $15 billion that Russia had made available before the protests. But that comes with an insistence on austerity and economic changes that will inflict considerable pain, and it is unclear if Europe or the United States will be willing to do more."

That sounds precisely like the Banana Republic prescriptions that impoverished almost all of Africa, the Caribbean, and South America since all those American-trained and funded coups of the 60s and 70s. Same old game, same old (and wealthy) players, in a world order wear the leaders and the rapacious, exploitative money-hoarders are (in many cases literally) the same people. I hope the Ukrainians can fend off rapacious foreign corporations despite significant pressure from countries like the USA, and tax there own oligarchs to something approaching fairness. That way, no austerity.

I would not be so cavalier about Civil War in the US. The last two President were not merely opposed by his opposition, he symbolized everything they find repugnant in a human being. At least that is how I viewed Bush II and how it seems the Republicans see Obama. We have a deep identity crisis and these kinda things do not lend themselves to negotiation, If you fear your loss will be your eradication or the disappearance of your way of life, negotiation is harder. Only if there is broad consensus can elections function smoothly. That is why so many who lose elections try to hang on or people lose elctions and stage revolutions.

The "great divide" within Ukraine is greatly exaggerated in the West, thanks to the crafty media influence of Moscow. In reality, it's more like Dem and GOP voting states in the US. Will America start a war or split over these voting patters? Of course not.
The problem is that propaganda and hate speech of Russian media, as well as state-controlled media and TV in Ukraine, has invaded the minds of lots of people in the region and abroad. However, in Ukraine the regime has lost control of most of the media outlets today, and they will start telling the truth tomorrow. Once people will see the findings of vast corruption by the state officials, their allegiances will shatter.
To those concerned about Russian invasion, Ukraine today is too big of a challenge for Putin to undertake. He will attack, but unlikely with military.
The major issue for Ukraine now, there's way to many corruption cases to prosecute, basically all branches of the govt, army, courts, law enforcement, army, etc. In terms of help, the West could assist with tracking down billions of dollars siphoned by the corrupt officials and their families to foreign banks.

When a large and widespread housing bubble burst in 2007, it created suffering with little hope of recovery without federal aid. Capitalism was subject to failure. If we allow markets we depend on to fail, then we end up with unnecessary Margaret Thatcher inspired suffering. A libertarian theory of free markets that could transition the private sector into a system that lets iconic, big businesses fail as a result of a recession, is still susceptible to another housing bubble. The proposed austerity politics of today would not treat the problem nearly as sufficiently as more stimulus, while not preventing another economic meltdown in the future. The disparity in wealth in this country is why the vast majority of citizens live off credit, mortgages they hope will inflate and find less opportunities for upward mobility than they deserve for their work.
http://kmorte.blogspot.com/

Josh- it's called nationalism, tradition- whatever the word maybe... the dream of most Ukrainians is to have a united country where Ukrainians have lived for milllennia.. Ukrainians believe that the ethnic Russians are outsiders at best, invaders at worst.  The communists transplanted millions and displaced Ukrainians in the East from the 1920's through the 1950's-60's.  Something of a similar nature happened when England shipped thousands of Scots to northern Ireland and displaced the Irish Catholics there- all hell broke loose, to the point that many Scots(Irish) fled to the U.S.  Ukrainians will be hard to convince to split the country- they want Ukraine for Ukrainians and no Russian interference....- long history, long memories.
The scariest thing about this must be the loss of a plutocrat's private horde. Americans might start to get ideas.

The Communist Party should have been banned in Ukraine in 1991. Its members were responsible for too many crimes against humanity since its inception. The Party of Regions, as we see today through the newly discovered evidence, was involved in incredible nationwide corruption schemes, as well as in crimes against humanity associated with the recent tragedy called the Bloody Thursday.

The latest hint that the opposition might not subscribe to the democratic process is the banning in the western areas of the Party of Regions as well as the Communist Party. Whatever one thinks of either of them isn't at issue - they have a sizable base of support, and to disenfranchise those people is an ominous beginning to this "freedom".

Dr. K,

In my view what you write about austerity is correct but what is very difficult to understand is how the proponents of austerity persist. They seem to be avoiding actions at the local, state, and federal level that would stimulate the economy. No one in the media save your own blog is consistently making the case for a continuation of a stimulus & policy actions that would broadly share the modest amount of economic growth that we have seen.

I have also been amazed by the concerns expressed by responsible economists about price increases. The reports about the recently released 2008 transcripts of Federal Reserve are shocking. 2008 was already showing a bump up in foreclosures & weakness in home prices. People were being laid off or being threatened of being laid off. Credit was drying up and by the end of 2008 credit was frozen for regular income earners. It was painful for me and my adult sons who experienced a personal depression at a bad time.

I can't understand why it is so difficult to determine the economy's potential & begin to act on eliminating the barriers to achieving its full potential. I was also amazed that we were laying off school teachers during the great contraction.

You were heroic in your efforts but the effort did not seem to change the attitude of the policy crowd, except for President Obama, who started saying the right thing. He got off the deficit cutting bandwagon and the Bowles-Simpson track. That is progress.

Everybody forgets that the American revolution was unique, because it was one of the few in the world's history that worked almost straight off. France had a long tortured path with not one but two revolutions, and many decades before the country was settled. Remember Napoleon?

Countries in the Arab Spring need time to do things in their countries which they never did before. People of the Ukraine need time to settle their country and right it.

This is exhilarating! To see many peoples of the world working for a better future for all of their countries. Good luck to them all and may God be with them.

What makes people think that the US is the cheerleader here? There were some talks about agreements with the EU, that's it. Maidan had no support or any influence from the US, both officially and otherwise. In fact, for a long time US officials were well aware of vast corruption and human right violations in Ukraine, and they did nothing, maybe because of issues with Russia, or simply because there were much more important issues to take care of. I'm afraid we want to take credit should the "liberation" of Ukraine succeed. However, we need to admit we did nothing, especially in terms of timely sanctions against oligarchs and corrupt senior officials, which would likely prevent the Bloody Thursday in Ukraine from happening. And those sanctions would cost us zero tax payer money. Zero.

Of course these stirring events are welcome. Yet as the US charges ahead to cleave Ukraine away from Russia, think for a moment how we would feel if this was happening in Mexico with Russia as the cheerleader. Not too good, no?

Think long and hard on this;

The Republicans and their military are after Russia while the Democrats are trying to hold the leash on the mad dogs of war.

Help us O-Ba-Ma, you're our only hope.

No missiles in Poland and criticize the actions of Senator McAhab.

While I have no use for the violent authoritarianism of Yanyukovych we should remember the wholesale use of gunfire by police in LA in the Watts and King Riots and see if we can't do better with our own political process.

The protesters are not leaving the central square, Maidan, until Yanukovych is resigned and prosecuted. In fact, the newly formed Civil Commission of Investigation and Prosecution of Crimes Against Humanity has already compiled a list of 25 top government officials believed to be responsible for deaths of civilians. Some those officials have already fled the country. The confirmed death toll as of today is 82, but there are missing and injured still in critical condition. The number of hospitalized victims is close to 500 in the capital only, others have been transported for treatment to their hometowns or abroad.

All you see here is men in black (to paraphrase Johnny Cash) evidence of a miserable, poor, and lonely country fighting for freedom.  Obviously this thing is far from over and will once again involve the US and Russia determining who is the strongest.  Same happened with Georgia next door who voted for the US support under Bush-2 and were successful.  Let's see who is the winner this time.

With changed global political landscapeblocr the last two decades, not only the great games of geopolitical dominance by imperial powers of past centuries have become redundant, but caricaturing those dead emperors and disintegrated empires by their present day inheritors too looks funny and invites ridicule. For, with collapse of the Soviet Union bloc though history might not have come to an end, nonetheless the historiography that looked history from above seems to have given way to the history being enacted on the ground by the common folks. To the chagrin of the Russian strongman Putin or his ilks what's happening in different regions from the Middle East, Latin America, South Esst Asia to Ukraine is that dimension of history long suppressed under the authoritarian overweight, now lending new meaning to liberal values like  freedom, dignity and self rule, that is comprehensible to the native people, and not dictated from above. The days of seeking hegemonic control and dominance over people's lives are numbered in a world undergoing cataclysmic changes now.
I'm pretty sure he's singing "Thank Heaven for Little Girls," isn't he?

Ukraine is  a huge part of what is thought of as Russian culture. Ukraine was never in the same boat as Estonia or Lithuania. I see that Western Ukraine wants to be Europe, much as the Moscow elite have long have a love/hate relationship with Western culture. The pro Yanukovych faction won the last election. Now elections do not lead to a democratic society by itself, but I do not think anyone has quite got the balance right. I have a strange feeling the reportage in this instance is seeing black and white when maybe it is more complex and deeper than it seems. Putin is very popular in Russia. Do we all want what we say we want? How can we tell?

It is best that Russia let this go. Mr. Putin is a determined despot in his own non-right, but it would be wise if he were to say good-bye to Ukraine and even help it as it seeks the support of the EU. Anything else will smell of the old USSR, of which Mr. Putin was a significant part.

I would have a hard time believing that the very same people who fought Yanukovych with all that danger, so many lost their lives, and the threat the Army could have been sent after them will now just sit down and roll over for another crooked politician. I make no judgement on Tymoshenko, I believe that any leader who will rise from this turmoil will be throughly scrutinized by the people of Ukraine.

We witnessed the Orange Revolution a few years back. This uprising makes the Orange Revolution seem innocent. This is my opinion, I would like to hear from a Ukrainian if I am close or not.

Shark, you're probably right.  Simon Sez is a fool.  "RUSSIA help liberate UKR ffrom fascist Ukrainians?"  Putin is a fascist who uses fear to govern. Comparing Ukrainian protesters to this tyrant is a bad joke.  The Ukraine will end up in the EU camp and  hopefully, the Russians will overthrow the  dictator when the oil price bottoms.  The Russians are learning something about true bravery from their courageous neighbor.
